hedline.hl1: Dell Planning to Offer Digital Audio Receiver

abstract.p: Dell Computer Corp says it plans to introduce PC-based digital audio receiver that will allow MP3 and WMA music files stored on personal computer to be played through home stereo system or in any room of the house; photo of receiver (S)

block.p: Making its first foray into consumer electronics -- but still tethered to the personal computer -- the Dell Computer Corporation said yesterday that it was preparing to introduce a PC-based digital audio receiver that would allow MP3 and WMA music files stored on a personal computer to be played through a home stereo system or in any room of the house.

The new Dell receiver, which is expected to go on sale at www.gigabuys.com in August for $249 (or $199 when bought with a Dell Dimension computer), is a small, radio-style box that uses an HPNA (Home Phoneline Networking Alliance) version 2.0 or Ethernet network to tap into the digital music files stored on a personal computer. An HPNA 2.0 network card for the PC costs between $50 and $70, depending on the manufacturer. It allows the digital audio receiver to pull MP3 songs and playlists, managed by either Music Match or Real Audio software, into the receiver through a home's existing phone jacks. The receiver itself can be plugged into the home stereo's RCA jack to fill the house with music, or it can be set up with an optional $99 set of Acoustic Research speakers to bring the PC music to any room where music is wanted.

Dell's new audio appliance shares the same basic design as S3 Inc.'s Rio Digital Audio Receiver, which was demonstrated last month, but unlike the Rio, the Dell has a retro-style radio control panel. The Rio music appliance will be sold in consumer electronics and computer retail stores later this summer for $299.95, which includes the receiver, an H.P.N.A. 2.0 network card, two phone cords and an RCA cable.
